review.title: Multi-period Trading Prediction Markets with Connections to Machine Learning
review.abstract: We present a new model for prediction markets, in which we use risk measures to model agents and introduce a market maker to describe the trading process. This specific choice on modelling tools brings us mathematical convenience. The analysis shows that the whole market effectively approaches a global objective, despite that the market is designed such that each agent only cares about its own goal. Additionally, the market dynamics provides a sensible algorithm for optimising the global objective. An intimate connection between machine learning and our markets is thus established, such that we could 1) analyse a market by applying machine learning methods to the global objective, and 2) solve machine learning problems by setting up and running certain markets.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: After the mainstream interest in "big data," a valuable direction for machine learning is to build distributed, scalable, and self-motivating systems that can be organized to solve large-scale problems. Recently, forecasting markets (Wolfers and Zitzewitz, 2004) have shown promise to be the abstract framework for machine learners to design these systems (Storkey, 2011). Since Pennock and Wellman (1996), researchers have spent decades making connections between machine learning and prediction markets, but this problem has not yet been solved well. One reason is that the framework of prediction markets is somehow too flexible, and to analyze the markets for machine learning, one must first specify a market model to describe the prediction markets.

sections.heading: 3 Preferences on Assets
sections.text: The preferred sequence of two of an agent's assets is measured using a functional f: X: X: R, so that the agent prefers one asset X over the other when and only when f (X) > f (Y), and that the agent is indifferent between X and Y when and only when f (X) = f (Y). There are many theories for selecting and analyzing a particular form of f. These include the expected benefit theory (EUT) (von Neumann and Morgenstern, 2007), the dual benefit theory (Yaari, 1987), risk measures (Artzner et al., 1999), and so on. EUT is perhaps the most popular theory in economics and game theory, while risk measures are often found in financial literature. We opt for risk measures to model the agent's behavior. In this section, we introduce risk measures while detailing the justification of the use of risk measures and their relationship to EUT section 6.

sections.heading: 3.2 Rational Choices
sections.text: Remember that a portfolio that results in a higher value of f (X) is preferred, so an agent's preferred portfolio should be the one that maximizes f, which we call {w, X} opt. The behavior of the choice of {w, X} opt is called rational choice, and an agent is rational when he always chooses {w, X} opt as his trade target. As within our framework, a rational agent chooses only his own target (3,7), this property seems to prevent us from linking markets with machine learning methods, since the latter always aim to achieve certain global goals.

sections.heading: 4 Multi-period Trading Markets
sections.text: In this section, we will build a market that defines the price of each security. However, all trading agents may only trade with one market maker whose trades are driven by a market maker. "Multi-period" is used to indicate that the prices of the securities may vary at different times and that agents may trade with the market maker in multiple times (Fo'llmer et al., 2004). The market maker is introduced to simplify the market mechanism and make the market run efficiently. Furthermore, it is difficult to characterize the trading process in markets with unspecified mechanisms, and these markets may not operate efficiently. For example, there may not be a consistent agreement between agents on how much should be paid to buy / sell a share of a security. Furthermore, an agent who cannot find a certain amount of shares (Chen and Pennock, 2007) may provide a way to simplify the trading process by introducing a market maker (Hanson, 2007, an agent who is a market maker for each security).

sections.text: The idea of developing models for forecasting markets and discussing their relationship to optimization is not new, and a few significant advances have been made in recent years. sections.heading: 6.1 Risk measures and EUT
sections.text: First, the output value of a risk measure can be treated as a risk-free asset, and standard linear operations are well defined for this. In comparison, an expected benefit gives a figure that has only abstract meaning, i.e. measuring the degree of satisfaction of the agent. Furthermore, risk measures by definition force the invariance of the translation, but expected utility functions generally do not have this characteristic. Translation invariance can always separate wealth w from the risky asset X, which implies that the optimal portfolio does not depend on w. This saves us the difficulty of associating w with the aggregation weights, since the relationship between them is highly inconsistent and varies dramatically between different uses (Storkey et al., 2012). Finally, we could always derive risk taking from risk mitigation (Fillmer et al.).

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: We show that our market as a whole optimises certain global objectives through its market dynamics. On the basis of this result, we establish close links between machine learning and markets. A future work would be to carry out a detailed analysis of this framework using the tools of convex optimisation (Boyd and Vandenberghe, 2004). A particularly interesting topic is the search for the conditions under which the market will converge. As we have observed, stochasticity occurs when a large number of agents are involved, which is probably the nature of any real market (Penna et al., 2012).

Storkey (2011) defines and analyses a type of prediction markets based on definitions on the markets, securities, and agents. Agents are modelled by EUT, that is, an agent is rational by maximising its expected utility. By analysing the equilibrium status of the market the author shows that the market can aggregate beliefs from agents to output a probability distribution over the future events. The author does not discuss precise market mechanisms or give the global objective of the market, which makes it difficult to link these markets to optimisation procedures. Another important progress is given by Penna et al. (2012), who apply the market scoring rules as the market mechanism to the framework of Storkey (2011). The work shows that with a large population of agents whose portfolios are drawn from a demand distribution, the whole market implements stochastic mirror descent. One concern is that they suggest using EUT to model agents but they do not use it to solve the optimal portfolios for the agents. This problem is partially solved by Premachandra and Reid (2013), who derives the solution for a certain type of expected utilities. A similar setting is also studied by Sethi and Vaughan (2013). They focus more on the convergence of the market dynamics, and show how markets can aggregate beliefs by using numerical evidences.

metadata.abstractText: We present a new model for prediction markets, in which we use risk measures to model agents and introduce a market maker to describe the trading process. This specific choice on modelling tools brings us mathematical convenience. The analysis shows that the whole market effectively approaches a global objective, despite that the market is designed such that each agent only cares about its own goal. Additionally, the market dynamics provides a sensible algorithm for optimising the global objective. An intimate connection between machine learning and our markets is thus established, such that we could 1) analyse a market by applying machine learning methods to the global objective, and 2) solve machine learning problems by setting up and running certain markets.
